I.  THE PROPOSAL 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed 
policy-based grant to Tuvalu for the Strengthened Public Financial Management Program. 
 
2.  The program is designed to support the medium-term fiscal framework and multiyear 
policy reform matrix of the Government of Tuvalu by developing policies and processes to 
improve its capacity for fiscal management.1 
 
II.  THE PROGRAM 
A.  Rationale 
3.  Tuvalu is an extremely small and remote island country. Its land area of 26 square 
kilometers (km2) covers nine coral atolls and reef islands that are spread across more than 
900,000 km2 of the Pacific Ocean. More than half of its approximately 11,000 people reside 
on the 2.8 km2 island of Fongafale in the Funafuti Atoll. Tuvalu has no known mineral resources 
and few  exports. It  is almost  entirely  dependent  on  external  aid  and  revenues  to finance 
essential food and fuel imports. The government generates 88% of all economic activity and few 
opportunities exist for private sector development.2 
 
4.  Given the government’s dominant role, sound management of public finance is critical to 
the  country’s  economic  performance.  The  government’s  revenue  base  is  narrow  and 
significantly exposed to external variables. Revenues come mainly from the real income of the 
development partner-financed Tuvalu Trust Fund (TTF), fishing license fees, licensing royalties 
for the commercial use of the country’s top-level domain (.tv), and grants.3 Receipts from fishing 
licenses and domain use fees account for around 40% of total revenue. Import duties and 
excise and other trade taxes account for only 10% of total revenue and are unlikely to become a 
greater source of revenue in the medium term due to Tuvalu’s commitment to free trade terms 
under the Pacific Island Countries Trade Agreement.4 Government revenue is difficult to predict 
accurately and is often highly volatile. Revenues from the TTF have helped to smooth the flow 
of revenues to the government from year to year. 
 
5.  The TTF, which was established in 1987 to contribute to the long-term financial viability 
of Tuvalu, provides an additional source of revenue for recurrent government expenditures. The 
TTF  was  initially  capitalized  with  A$27.1  million  in  contributions from  several  development 
partners, including Australia (A$8.0 million) and New Zealand (A$8.3 million). As of 31 March 
2012, the trust fund’s market value stood at A$122.9 million, or around 3.5 times Tuvalu’s 2011 
gross domestic product (GDP). The trust fund aims to generate a real annual rate of return of 
4.5%, which is calculated using Australia’s consumer price index. In years when the market 
value of the trust fund exceeds its real maintained value, the surplus is transferred to the 
Consolidated Investment Fund (CIF) within the government’s Consolidated Fund (its main bank 
account) and invested in a mix of cash and fixed interest securities. The CIF also serves as a

internet domain and from fishing license fees, and acts as a revenue stability mechanism. 
Withdrawals  from  the  CIF  are  used  to  fund  the  recurrent  budget  as  well  as  capital 
reinvestments. The CIF contributed around 15% of each of the annual government budgets 
during 1990–2008. 
 
6.  Because its returns have fallen short of the target in recent years, the TTF has not 
added to the CIF since 2008. Given ongoing low returns in the markets in which the TTF can 
invest, contributions to the CIF are unlikely to begin again until 2014. By this time the slight 
recovery in the value of the trust fund in 2012 and the shift in portfolio strategy, from static 
benchmark-matching to dynamic targeting of risk and return, is expected to push its returns 
above its maintained value. Despite strong efforts by the government to contain the deficit in 
2011 and modest deficit forecasts for 2012–2014, the government needs to rebuild the CIF to 
help smooth volatile revenue flows and provide a fiscal buffer in the event of shocks. This is 
particularly important given global economic uncertainty and the fact that GDP growth in Tuvalu 
is expected to be only 1.4% in 2012 and 1.3% in 2013.  
 
7.  The economy expanded by a real annual rate of only 2.4% per annum during 2007–
2011 and Tuvalu’s growth outlook remains subdued. The country has recovered only slowly 
from the global economic crisis, which reduced the value of the TTF at the same time as 
government’s cash reserves in the CIF were being drained through high spending. Falling 
remittances due to the decline in seafarer employment abroad during the global crisis hurt 
household incomes. An unfavorable foreign exchange trend has aggravated these problems. 
Tuvalu’s currency, the Australian dollar, has strengthened against the US dollar, which is the 
currency  in  which  the  earnings  of  the  country’s  international  seafarers  and  much  of  the 
government’s income are dominated.5 
 
8.  Tuvalu’s growth strategy is set out in its National Strategy for Sustainable Development, 
2005–2015. 6The  strategy  recognizes  that  strengthening  public  sector  management  and 
improving the private sector environment are key drivers for change in Tuvalu. This is consistent 
with the focus put on these goals by the Asian Development Bank’s (ADB) Pacific Approach as 
well as ADB’s country operations business plan.7 Developing effective fiscal management to 
complement private sector development has been a long-standing goal of ADB support to 
Tuvalu. 
 
1.  Government’s Policy Reform Matrix for Budget Support 
9.  In consultation with the International Monetary Fund (IMF), the government developed a 
medium-term fiscal framework in June 2012 to insulate its fiscal position from revenue volatility 
and global shocks and maintain fiscal sustainability (see table). The fiscal framework was based 
on the government’s multiyear policy reform matrix (PRM), prepared in March 2012 with the 
collaboration of ADB, the governments of Australia and New Zealand, and the World Bank. 
Subsequently, the projected budget outturn for 2012 reflects both planned expenditure cuts and 
also increased grants.8

10.  The PRM has four main areas: governance, social development, education and human 
resources, and macroeconomic growth and stability. In March 2012, Tuvalu’s development 
partners agreed to help implement the PRM through a series of budget support operations, as 
well as through coordinated policy dialogue and supervision; technical assistance (TA); and, in 
the case of Australia and New Zealand, increased scholarship awards. Implementing the PRM 
will help ease the government’s fiscal constraints by boosting economic growth, improving tax 
collections, reducing nonpriority expenditures, and unlocking additional budget support (footnote 
2). 
 
11.  The PRM aims to establish a framework to make the budget sustainable and to keep the 
budget  deficit  below  10%  of  GDP  during  2012–2014.  This  is  to  be  accomplished  by 
strengthening fiscal controls, making budgeting and budget execution more effective, improving 
service  delivery,  protecting  essential  social  services,  reforming  the  government’s  public 
enterprises  (which  include  all  areas  of  government  operations  that  have  business-like 
characteristics, including government corporations), and increasing revenue mobilization. When 
these reforms have been properly accomplished, Tuvalu’s development partners will provide the 
budget support that will enable the government to rebuild its reserves in the CIF (para. 6). 
 
12.  The government and its development partners appreciate that this must be a carefully 
sequenced  incremental  process.  ADB,  Australia,  New  Zealand,  and  the World  Bank  have 
agreed to provide financial and technical support for a government-led reform program. ADB will 
finance reform measures in the first phase of the PRM for 2012. This will include identifying 
more steps to strengthen fiscal management. The governments of Australia and New Zealand 
and the World Bank have agreed to link their provision of budget support in 2013 to the ongoing 
implementation of these reform measures. 
 
13.  To restore fiscal sustainability, strong measures will also be needed to boost revenues. 
In 2012, the government increased the Tuvalu consumption tax (TCT) rate from 3% to 4% and 
made a greater effort to collect delinquent taxes. The 2012 budget also introduced measures to 
bring  large  public  enterprises,  particularly  the  Tuvalu  Electricity  Corporation,  the  Tuvalu 
Telecom Corporation, and the Vaiaku Lagi Hotel (VLH), that are not paying consumption tax 
under the TCT net. The government is to increase the TCT rate to 7% in 2013 and to 10% by

4 
2015. To maintain competitiveness and help broaden the tax base, the government will also 
take steps to lower income tax rates. 
 
14.  Expenditures are being restrained by reducing entitlements and containing recurrent 
costs. The government has halted allocations for government-funded scholarships and reduced 
the accommodation component of the government-funded overseas medical treatment scheme. 
Special development expenditures, which are mainly capital projects for such things as boat 
ramps  and  jetties  in  the  outer  island,  have  been  scaled  back.  Other  measures  that  the 
government  is  considering  include  a  freeze  in  real  government  wages  in  2013  and 
implementation of additional cost-reduction measures for the medical treatment and scholarship 
schemes. 
 
15.  These measures will be complemented by critically needed reforms in the government’s 
eight public enterprises, which dominate the country’s commercial landscape.9 Only two of them 
reported profits in 2011—the National Bank of Tuvalu and the Tuvalu Electricity Corporation. 
Most are not only loss-making—and thus a burden on the government budget—but also provide 
substandard service.  
 
2.  Fiscal Policy and Management Capacity Issues 
 
16.  Tuvalu has a relatively strong annual budget formulation process and the government 
can achieve fiscal discipline and effective strategic allocation of resources if it adheres to its 
medium-term fiscal framework.10 However, government budgeting is weak on credibility and 
predictability and budget execution is poor. This means that deficits can suddenly increase and 
that spending agencies lack the timely, accurate financial information they need to manage their 
activities effectively. Efficient service delivery is also undermined by the lack of a government-
wide  policy  and  regulatory framework for  procurement. The  current  practice  of  purchasing 
goods and services through established suppliers provides no guarantees that the government 
is getting value for its money. The tender process for works contracts, under the Public Tenders 
Board regulations, lacks all the checks and balances needed to ensure that procurement is 
competitive and transparent.11   
 
3.  Public Enterprise Reform Issues 
17.  ADB’s  first  policy-based  program  in  Tuvalu—the  Improved  Financial  Management 
Program—was  instrumental  in  addressing  weaknesses  in  government  oversight  of  public 
enterprises.12 The  program  built  on  previous  ADB  support  for  public  sector  management, 
including the TA for capacity development for public financial management, which supported the 
government’s  efforts  to  implement  its  public  enterprise  reform  program.13 It  contributed  to 
government approval of a Public Enterprise Reform Policy in 2009 and enactment of the Public

Enterprise Act 2010, as well as the establishment of the public enterprise monitoring unit in the 
Ministry of Finance and Economic Development (MFED) in 2009 to monitor and manage the 
performance of all public enterprises. However, it was found that such reforms in Tuvalu can 
take longer to achieve than is initially expected. Due to the tight fiscal situation and a high 
turnover  of  skilled  and  experienced  staff,  the  government  made  less  progress  than  ADB 
envisaged  in  follow-on  actions  on  reforms,  such  as  the  operationalization  of  a  debt  risk 
management and mitigation policy and the appointment of a banking commissioner.14 The 
nationalization of the electricity corporation in November 2011 was also a setback to public 
enterprise reform although the Tuvalu Electricity Corporation (Repeal) Act 2011 will not be put 
into effect. 
 
18.  The overall design of the program is based on ADB’s experiences with the Improved 
Financial Management Program in Tuvalu and policy-based lending programs in the Pacific 
more generally.  The  lessons from  these  activities  emphasize  the  importance  of  promoting 
country ownership by ensuring that such programs (i) are realistic, relatively simple in scope, 
and well within a country’s capacities; (ii) embody a long-term perspective and commitment so 
that each program is seen as the next step in a sequenced reform process; and (iii) promote 
strong development partner collaboration through dialogue and the coordination of missions and 
TA support.15 This design approach is also consistent with advice received from the IMF, as 
well as lessons from ADB’s special evaluation on promoting good governance in the Pacific.16 
For these reasons, the Program will be a single-tranche operation that will require all necessary 
policy actions are accomplished in advance of grant effectiveness. This will ensure that all the 
PRM reform measures earmarked for implementation in 2012—which are all essential building 
blocks for the reform actions to be supported by Australia, New Zealand, and other development 
partners in 2013 and 2014—are accomplished before effectiveness.  
 
B.  Impact and Outcome 
19.  The impact will be the achievement of fiscal sustainability of the Tuvalu government. 
This is a priority of the National Strategy for Sustainable Development and exemplified by the 
reform measures in the PRM. The impact will be measured against specific fiscal targets in 
Tuvalu’s medium-term fiscal framework and verified by regular IMF staff missions and IMF 
Article IV consultation reports. The outcome will be improved fiscal management capacity. This 
will be reflected in improved fiscal management capacity in the event of shocks. 
 
C.  Outputs 
20.  The program is structured around PRM objectives in the government’s national plan to 
exercise  sound  macroeconomic  and  fiscal  management,  exert  fiscal  discipline  so  that 
government budgets are fiscally sustainable, and strengthen and improve public enterprise 
management. To achieve these objectives, the Program focused on the achievement of three 
outputs in 2012. 
 
21.  Output  1:  Improved  fiscal  management  policy.  The  program  supported  the 
finalization of a PFM reform road map and a procurement policy.

15 ADB. 2011. Policy Brief: Policy-Based Programs for the Pacific Islands. Manila.

22.  The PFM reform road map allows the government to identify areas of weakness and to 
chart a sequence of reform measures. It has improved the government’s capacity to manage 
critical PFM reforms strategically and cohesively by prioritizing and sequencing reform actions 
properly and coordinating development partner support. The road map was developed with 
support  from  the  Pacific  Financial  Technical  Assistance  Centre  and  approved  by  the 
government cabinet on 27 July 2012. The government has already begun implementing some 
elements of the road map: an annual budget calendar has been published; cash reconciliations 
are now being completed on a monthly basis; and public accounts have been brought up-to-
date, with 2009–2011 accounts having been audited. 
 
23.  The procurement policy has clarified and strengthened regulatory requirements and 
improved incentives in the public procurement process for competition, value for money, and 
accountability through strengthening of tender and procurement procedures. The policy was 
developed by the Attorney General’s Office with support from ADB and the Australian Agency 
for  International  Development  (AusAID)  and  was  approved  by  the  cabinet  on  25  October 
2012.17 A draft of the procurement policy was provided to ADB for review prior to finalization to 
ensure that all necessary fiduciary requirements were met, in accordance with international best 
practice. 
 
24.  Output  2:  Improved  fiscal  management  processes.  The  program  supported  the 
identification and development of fiscal ratios, which are practical management tools to maintain 
fiscal aggregates within agreed bounds. 
 
25.  The use of the ratios to set fiscal management targets will complement the principles of 
fiscal  responsibility  contained  in  Tuvalu’s  Public  Finance  Ordinance  1982  and  Financial 
Instructions 1990 and will build on the budget benchmark performance criteria previously used 
by Australia and New Zealand as incentives for budget support. The ratios include targets for 
domestic  revenue,  domestic  expenditure,  personnel  costs,  and  government  borrowing  as 
proportions of GDP. They have been developed with support from ADB and were approved by 
the cabinet  on  19  July  2012. The ratios  were  used to guide the  preparation  of the  2013 
budget.18 
 
26.  Output  2  is  expected  to  improve  Tuvalu’s  budgetary  position  by  strengthening  the 
government’s ability to track budget performance on a quarterly basis and to measure this 
performance against its medium-term fiscal projections. This will allow it to take any corrective 
action necessary in a timely manner. 
 
27.  Output  3:  Selected  public  enterprise  rationalization. The  program facilitated  the 
government’s efforts to advance its rationalization plans for the VLH, the Tuvalu Philatelic 
Bureau (TPB), the Tuvalu Post Office (TPO), and the Tuvalu Travel Office (TTO). This included 
the approval of a draft management contract for the hotel and the merging of the TPB, the TPO, 
and the TTO, which are retail businesses. 
 
28.  The hotel has performed poorly in financial terms from 2004 to 2011. A scoping study 
undertaken with ADB TA in 2011 recommended that the VLH be sold through an international 
tender process. As a transitional arrangement, the government has opted to contract the hotel’s

29.  ADB will help the government publish the invitation to tender for the VLH management 
contract through local and regional news media. ADB TA (footnote 15) helped to ensure that all 
supporting documents such as the draft management contract were prepared and approved by 
the cabinet.19 Cabinet approved the draft management contract and the advertisement for 
invitation to tender on 26 October 2012. 
 
30.  The merger of the TPB, the TPO, and the TTO into one entity—called Tuvalu Post and 
Travel—will help cut the operating costs of, and subsidies for, these public enterprises and 
reduce  the  government’s  fiscal  losses.  All  three  of  the  retail  operations  are  encountering 
increasingly stiff competition, that is, from newer technology, including email, telephone calls 
and travel bookings conducted over the internet. ADB TA (footnote 15) helped the government 
begin the merger through cabinet approval of the transfer of its shares in TPB and of the assets 
and liabilities of TPO and TTO to Tuvalu Post and Travel at an agreed price and with all 
necessary documentation completed. Cabinet approved the merger on 26 October 2012. 
 
31.  Output 3 will contribute to fiscal sustainability. Reform of these public enterprises will 
free resources that can be used more effectively in other priority budget areas. 
 
D.  Development Financing Needs  
 
32.  The program is estimated to cost $5.2 million. 
 
33.  The government has requested a grant not exceeding $2.35 million from ADB’s Special 
Funds resources to help finance the program.  
 
34.  ADB  is  basing  the  size  of  its  $2.35  million  grant  on  the  government’s  financing 
requirements, the cost of the government’s reform efforts, and the importance of rebuilding the 
government’s fiscal buffer in the CIF. While this is not a cofinancing arrangement, this effort will 
be part of a joint undertaking with other development partners. Australia has pledged A$500,000 
and New Zealand NZ$400,000 ($326,623) for the 2012 financial year, while the World Bank has 
indicated that it will consider providing budget support for 2013 and 2014. Projections of budget 
financing requirements indicate a fiscal deficit of 5.3% of GDP in 2012, equivalent to A$14.9 
million, without grant support from development partners.  
 
E.  Implementation Arrangements 
35.  Program management. The MFED will be the executing agency and will oversee and 
coordinate timely implementation of the agreed policy actions (paras. 21–31). The implementing 
agencies will be the MFED’s public enterprise monitoring unit; the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, 
Environment, Trade, Labour and Tourism; and the Ministry of Transport and Communication. 
Each  will  be  responsible for  undertaking  the  policy  actions  or  program  activities  under  its 
responsibilities. Ongoing TA will help the government fulfill program conditions (footnote 15). 
The  MFED  will  also  be  responsible  for  program  administration,  disbursements,  and 
                                                
19 ADB. 2009. Technical Assistance for the Pacific Private Sector Development Initiative, Phase 2. Manila. (TA 7430-
REG, for $3,000,000, approved on 10 December).

8 
maintenance of all program records. ADB and other development partners supporting the PRM 
process will help the government set up a high-level coordination and monitoring mechanism. It 
will  be  made  up  of  the  members  of  the  TTF  advisory  committee—representatives  of  the 
government and of AusAID and New Zealand Aid Program—and will monitor progress and 
oversee the implementation of the program and the activities of the MFED. 
 
36.  Implementation period. The program will be implemented from 31 March 2012 to 31 
December 2013, consistent with the government’s medium-term fiscal framework. Policy and 
operational changes agreed with the government and set out in the policy matrix will be put in 
place from 31 March 2012 to 29 October 2012. 
 
37.  Procurement  and  disbursement.  The  proceeds  of  the  grant  will  be  disbursed  in 
accordance with ADB’s simplification of disbursement procedures and related requirements for 
policy-based grants.20 The proceeds will be used to finance the foreign exchange cost of items 
produced and procured in ADB member countries, excluding items included in a list of ineligible 
items  and  imports  financed  by  other  bilateral  and  multilateral  sources. 21 Grant  proceeds 
disbursed against imports will require a certificate from the government stipulating that the value 
of the total imports of Tuvalu, minus its imports from nonmember countries, ineligible imports 
and imports financed under other official development assistance, is equal to or greater than the 
amount of the grant expected to be disbursed during a particular year. ADB will have the right to 
audit the use of the grant proceeds and to verify the accuracy of the government’s certification. 
 
38.  Tranches. The grant will be provided in a single tranche and will be disbursed upon 
satisfaction of grant effectiveness conditions—that is, fulfillment of all the actions in the program 
policy matrix. All policy actions have been accomplished. 
 
39.  Counterpart funds. Local currency generated from the grant will be directed to the 
government’s  bank  account  with  the  National  Bank  of  Tuvalu  to  allow  provision  of 
supplementary financing for the 2012 budget. 
 
40.  Program  performance  monitoring  and  evaluation.  The  MFED  will  establish  a 
performance evaluation system for the program within 3 months from grant effectiveness and 
maintain this. Using this system, the MFED will monitor the program and report to ADB on the 
implementation of policy actions and their impact on budget outcomes, in line with the program 
impact and outcome indicators agreed upon with the government. Because the impact of the 
Program will be felt beyond the period of its implementation, the MFED will continue monitoring 
until the beginning of 2014. The information will be included in the program completion report. 
This monitoring of the outcome and impact will also be useful to the government’s ongoing 
reform processes and PFM decision making. 
  
41.  Program review. The government shall undertake periodic reviews every 3 months 
during program implementation period to evaluate the scope, implementation arrangements, 
progress and achievement of the objectives of the program. In addition to the periodic reviews, 
a mid-term review shall take place during the first quarter of 2013. The government will ensure 
that ADB shall have the opportunity to participate in these reviews.

9 
III.  DUE DILIGENCE 
42.  The program’s major benefit will be its contribution to the Tuvalu government’s long-term 
fiscal sustainability. Fiscal sustainability will in turn help restore macroeconomic stability in the 
country  and  boost  growth.  Strengthened  PFM  will  also  improve  service  delivery,  which  is 
essential to making the growth process inclusive and to fostering employment and poverty 
reduction. 
 
A.  Economic and Financial 
43.  Improving the government’s spending allocation decisions and reducing the demand on 
the budget made by public enterprises will create fiscal space and allow the government to shift 
expenditures to priority areas. Tuvalu’s overall fiscal performance will thereby improve. Budget 
restraint and strengthened fiscal management will allow the government to rebuild its external 
revenue cushion and reduce its vulnerability to fiscal shocks. The program’s long-term impact 
will be greater government capacity for fiscal management, which will help bring the budget 
deficit below the target of 10% of GDP. 
 
B.  Governance 
44.  The  government’s  ability  to  implement  its  budget  is  integral  to  the  success  of  the 
program.  The  2011  public  expenditure  and  financial  accountability  assessment  for  Tuvalu 
(footnote 11) identified the areas of weaknesses in government budgeting processes. The 
subsequent implementation of the PFM reform roadmap—and, more broadly, the emphasis on 
improving  public  financial  management  in  the  PRM—demonstrates  the  government’s 
commitment to managing the budget credibly and effectively.22 
 
45.  ADB’s  Anticorruption  Policy  (1998,  as  amended  to  date)  was  explained  to,  and 
discussed  with,  the  government  and  the  MFEM.  Consistent  with  its  commitment  to  good 
governance, accountability, and transparency, ADB reserves the right to investigate, directly or 
through its agents, any alleged corrupt, fraudulent, collusive or coercive practices relating to the 
program.  To  support  these  efforts,  relevant  provisions  of  ADB’s  Anticorruption  Policy  are 
included in the grant agreement. 
  
C.  Poverty and Social 
46.  Improved PFM will have positive impacts on the delivery of social services. In the near 
term, rationalization of the state enterprises could lead to modest job losses. A clear transition 
schedule for redundancy will be accompanied by retraining or compensation to avert adverse 
social impacts and will be supported by ADB and other development partners. 
 
D.  Safeguards 
47.  Program activities will be confined to policy and institutional reforms and none of the 
activities  will  result  in,  or  lead  to,  involuntary  resettlement  or  affect  indigenous  people. 
Safeguard categories for environment, involuntary resettlement, and indigenous peoples are all 
C. No adverse environmental impacts have been identified. Public consultation has been carried 
out during the processing of the program and fact finding. 
                                                
22  Further assessment is available in the Sector Assessment (Summary): Public Sector Management (accessible 
from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2).

10 
E.  Risks and Mitigating Measures 
48.  The program faces three key risks:  
 
(i)  The narrow economic base leaves the country vulnerable to shocks. Should 
these  occur,  the  reform  focus  would  likely  switch  from  strengthening  public 
financial management to short-term stabilization. 
(ii)  The political consensus needed to mount program reforms could prove difficult to 
maintain, particularly for public enterprise reforms.  
(iii)  Capacity constraints and staff turnover could limit the government’s ability to 
manage the program. 
 
49.  The program design mitigates these risks. The rebuilding of fiscal reserves will help the 
government weather potential external shocks. Political consensus has been reinforced through 
the government’s ownership and leadership of the PRM process and the subsequent reform 
effort. In addition, MFED with support from ADB TA (footnote 15) have conducted a concerted 
outreach  program  to  build  wider  support  for  reform  among  parliamentarians  and  in  the 
community. Capacity constraints will be offset in part through new and ongoing TA provided by 
ADB and other partners. To mitigate the risk of overburdening institutions, the PRM presents a 
continuance of reforms that have been under preparation since 2009. Major risks and mitigating 
measures are described in detail in the risk assessment and risk management plan.23 
 
IV.  ASSURANCES AND CONDITIONS 
50.  The government and the MFED have assured ADB that implementation of the program 
shall  conform  to  all  applicable  ADB  policies,  including  those  concerning  anticorruption 
measures,  safeguards,  gender,  procurement,  consulting  services,  and  disbursement  as 
described in detail in the grant document. 
 
51.  The government and the MFED have agreed with ADB on certain covenants for the 
program, which are set forth in the grant agreement. The grant will become effective after ADB 
is satisfied that all conditions for the release of the program tranche, as specified in the policy 
matrix and set out in Attachment 2 to Schedule 2 of the grant agreement, have been complied 
with.  
 
V.  RECOMMENDATION 
52.  I am satisfied that the proposed policy-based grant would comply with the Articles of 
Agreement of the Asian Development Bank (ADB) and, acting in the absence of the President, 
under the provisions of Article 35.1 of the Articles of Agreement of ADB, I recommend that the 
Board  approve  the  grant  not  exceeding  $2,350,000  to  Tuvalu  from  ADB’s  Special  Funds 
resources for the Strengthened Public Financial Management Program, on terms and conditions 
that are substantially in accordance with those set forth in the draft grant agreement presented 
to the Board. 
 
Bindu N. Lohani 
Vice-President
